case.name: Comcare v Christina Foster [2006] FCA 6 (12 January 2006)

citances.sentence:
Liquor Licensing Act 1997 (SA); Gaming Machines Act 1992 (SA), referred to. Esso Australia Resources v Federal Commissioner of Taxation [1999] HCA 67 ; (1999) 201 CLR 49 ; J-Corp Pty Ltd v Australian Builders Labourers Federated Union of Workers (1992) 38 FCR 452 , applied. Boyes v Colins [2000] WASCA 344 ; (2000) 23 WAR 123 ; Comcare v Foster [2006] FCA 6 ; (2006) 150 FCR 301 , distinguished. Commissioner of Australian Federal Police v Propend Finance Pty Ltd [1996] HCA 3 ; (1997) 188 CLR 501 ; Telebooth Pty Ltd v Telstra Corporation Ltd [1994] VicRp 21 ; [1994] 1 VR 337 ; Attorney-General (NT) v Maurice [1986] HCA 80 ; (1986) 161 CLR 475 ; Mann v Carnell [1999] HCA 66 ; (1999) 201 CLR 1 ; Seven Network Ltd v News Ltd [2005] FCA 142 ; Waterford v Commonwealth [1987] HCA 25 ; (1987) 163 CLR 54 ; Grant v Downs [1976] HCA 63 ; (1976) 135 CLR 674 , discussed. THE PALACE GALLERY PTY LTD v POLICE [2008] SASC 305
Civil
ANDERSON J. Mr Blue submits that in this regard I am bound to follow a decision of the Full Court of Western Australia in Boyes v Colins [2000] WASCA 344 ; (2000) 23 WAR 123. He also refers to Comcare v Foster [2006] FCA 6 ; (2006) 150 FCR 301 at [41] - [52] where Greenwood J followed Boyes v Colins and not J-Corp .

10 Having regard to the significance of legal professional privilege in our jurisprudence and particularly the observations of the High Court that legal professional privilege is a rule of substantive law available to a person to resist the giving of information or the production of documents which would reveal communications between a client and his or her lawyer made for the dominant purpose of giving or obtaining legal advice or the provision of legal services, including representation in legal proceedings ( Daniels Corporation International Pty Ltd v Australian Competition and Consumer Commission [2002] HCA 49 ; (2002) 213 CLR 543 at 9, per Gleeson CJ, Gaudron, Gummow and Hayne JJ), and having regard to the observations in the authorities that legal professional privilege is not merely a rule of evidence but an 'important common law immunity' not confined to simply processes of discovery and inspection (note the authorities collected in Comcare v Foster [2006] FCA 6 ; (2006) 226 ALR 749 [31] --- [37]), it seems to me that the substantive question between the parties is one which ought not to be resolved on a guillotine order in the circumstances as they present.

Ms Fitzpatrick said such a document would almost certainly be the subject of a claim for legal professional privilege because it would have been prepared for the sole purpose of being used in these proceedings: see Esso Australia Resources; see also Comcare v Christina Foster [2006] FCA 6 .

9. Legal professional privilege is an exemption in the public interest, which is said to be founded in the principle that the promotion of justice can best be served by allowing a client to communicate fully and frankly with the client's legal adviser without fear of disclosure. It attaches to any communication, not merely a document. The accepted principles to be applied in determining whether a communication attracts legal professional privilege are set out in a recent Federal Court decision: Comcare v Christina Foster [2006] FCA 6.
